title: 109_s2111
content: The "Small Business Growth Initiative Act of 2005" may be cited as the Act. It introduces a credit for employee training expenses of small businesses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Small Business Growth Initiative Act of 2005 introduces a credit for employee training expenses of small businesses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The credit allows eligible small business employers to claim an amount exceeding the base amount of qualified training expenses paid or incurred for qualified employees. The base amount is determined based on the average expenses for all qualified employees over the previous three years, with a special rule for new businesses. The special rule for new businesses under the Small Business Growth Initiative Act of 2005 states that eligible small business employers with at least 1 full preceding taxable year but fewer than 3 preceding taxable years can use the amount of qualified training expenses paid in the previous year as the base amount. For start-up businesses without any full preceding taxable years, the base amount is zero. The Small Business Growth Initiative Act of 2005 allows eligible small business employers to claim a tax credit for qualified training expenses. The credit amount is limited to $1,000 per qualified employee ($500 for eligible small businesses) with a maximum of 5 employees. An eligible small business employer is defined as having an average of 2 to 100 employees in the preceding taxable year. The term 'qualified training expenses' refers to expenses for training a qualified employee by an eligible training provider. A 'qualified employee' is someone employed full-time by an eligible small business employer for at least 6 months, excluding highly compensated employees, physicians, and veterinarians. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a small business employee training credit under section 45N(a). This credit is for expenses related to training qualified employees by eligible small business employers. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new item in part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new item in part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. A small business employee training credit is established, with amendments applying to expenditures incurred after December 31, 2005. Additionally, an increased exclusion and other modifications are applicable to qualified small business stock. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the exclusion for gain from qualified small business stock held for more than 3 years. Conforming amendments are made to related sections of the Code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the exclusion for gain from qualified small business stock held for more than 3 years. Conforming amendments are made to related sections of the Code, including amendments to sections 163(d)(4)(B), 854(b)(5), 857(c)(2)(D), 301(f)(4), 306(a)(1)(D), 584(c), 702(a)(5), 854(a), 854(b)(2), and 857(c)(2). Subsection (c) of section 1202 is also amended. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the exclusion for gain from qualified small business stock held for more than 3 years. Subsection (c) of section 1202 is amended to exclude stock held among members of a controlled group. Amendments are made to related sections of the Code, including changes to the holding period requirement from 5 years to 3 years. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to repeal certain provisions related to tax preferences and limitations on eligible gains. This includes the repeal of the per-issuer limitation in section 1202(b) and the working capital limitation in section 1202(e)(6). The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to repeal certain provisions related to tax preferences and limitations on eligible gains. This includes changes to the redemption rules and exceptions for business purposes in Section 1202. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to repeal provisions related to tax preferences and limitations on eligible gains, including changes to Section 1202(e)(3) defining qualified trade or business. The amendments made by this section apply to stock issued after December 31, 2005. SEC. 4 extends increased expensing for small businesses by amending section 179 to replace "2008" with "2011". SEC. 5 addresses SBIR and STTR program expenditures. The Small Business Act is amended to increase SBIR and STTR program expenditures gradually from 2.5% in 2006 to 5.0% in 2011 and beyond. The Small Business Act is amended to gradually increase SBIR and STTR program expenditures from 0.3% in 2006 to 0.6% in 2011 and beyond. SEC. 6. EXPANSION OF CREDIT FOR SMALL EMPLOYER PENSION PLAN STARTUP COSTS. Amends section 45E(b) of the Internal Revenue Code to increase the credit amount from $500 to $1,000. Effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2005.
